misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the computer 'reads' the text of the prompt (the print statement) to understand the intended format of the user's input, assuming the Scanner will automatically ignore characters like parentheses and commas.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is a fundamental disconnect between System.out and System.in. The Scanner.nextDouble() method is completely unaware of what was previously printed to the console; it does not treat the prompt '(x1, y1):' as a template or mask. It will fail with an InputMismatchException if the user attempts to include the formatting suggested by the prompt.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the machine can distinguish between multiple input values (like x and y) within a single numeric string (like '00') based on the human context of the prompt asking for two points.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java Scanner uses whitespace as a delimiter by default. A string of characters like '00' or '50' is treated as a single numeric token. The student's model fails to account for the machine's requirement for explicit delimiters (spaces or enters) to separate inputs into distinct variables.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the Scanner is context-aware and can automatically parse numeric values out of a formatted string (like parentheses or commas) because those characters were included in the prompt, or that it can split a single numeric token into multiple variables based on the program's needs.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java Scanner is a token-based parser that uses whitespace as a default delimiter. It does not 'read' the preceding System.out.print text to understand the input format. If a user follows the prompt '(x1, y1):' and types '(0,0)', nextDouble() will fail. Similarly, if a user types '00' (as shown in the sample run), nextDouble() will consume the entire sequence as a single value.
